required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Does Knowing One's Estimated Colorectal Cancer Risk Influence Screening Behavior?
clinical_study.official_title: Does Knowing One's Estimated Colorectal Cancer Risk Influence Screening Behavior?

brief_summary.textblock: This study is designed to examine the impact of telephone-based colorectal cancer risk assessment on colorectal screening attitudes and behavior among previously unscreened adults ages 50 to 75.

detailed_description.textblock: Colorectal cancer (CRC) remains the 3rd most common cancer in the US. Most CRCs are preventable, but screening participation remains suboptimal. Several factors have been associated with screening compliance, such as perception of CRC risk. Here we study the impact of telephone-based administration of the National Cancer Institute Colorectal Cancer Risk Assessment Tool (CCRAT) compared to usual care.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: Usual care of generalized colorectal cancer screening education over telephone versus personalized risk assessment over telephone using National Cancer Institute Colorectal Cancer Risk Assessment Tool (CCRAT)

primary_outcome.measure: Screening Behavior: Differences in colorectal cancer screening completion rates between usual care (UC) and CCRAT
primary_outcome.description: Any CRC screening test completed including stool tests (FOBT (fecal occult blood test), FIT (immunochemical test for fecal blood), stool DNA test), colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, double contrast barium enema, CT colonography (virtual colonoscopy)

secondary_outcome.measure: Screening Behavior: Differences in colorectal cancer screening completion rates between usual care (UC) and CCRAT
secondary_outcome.description: Any CRC screening test completed including stool tests (FOBT (fecal occult blood test), FIT (immunochemical test for fecal blood), stool DNA test), colonoscopy, flexible sigmoidoscopy, double contrast barium enema, CT colonography (virtual colonoscopy)

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in intention to screen at 6 months and 12 months
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Immediate after intervention, 6 months and 1 year after intervention
secondary_outcome.description: Differences in progressive behavioral stages of adoption from precontemplation to contemplation to preparation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Colorectal cancer screening rates at 12 months as a function of CCRAT score
secondary_outcome.description: Screening completion at 12 months will be compared between the 3 tertiles of CCRAT score in the intervention group to determine whether there is any relationship between absolute CCRAT score and screening completion

other_outcome.measure: Risk perception: Health Belief Model Likert Scale
other_outcome.description: Differences in perception of one's own risk of colorectal cancer ranging from "very unlikely" (minimum) to "very likely" (maximum), with "very unlikely" representing the most favorable outcome of perceived risk and "very likely" representing the most unfavorable outcome of perceived risk.

other_outcome.measure: Fear: Health Belief Model Likert Scale
other_outcome.description: Presence of fear of discovering colorectal cancer on performing screening test ranging from "strongly disagree" (minimum) to "strongly agree" (maximum), with "strongly disagree" representing the most favorable outcome of fear and "strongly agree" representing the most unfavorable outcome of fear.

arm_group.description: Patients receive standardized general information about colorectal cancer screening over the telephone.

Patient receive personalized colorectal cancer risk assessment over the telephone by answering the questions as outlined in the National Cancer Institute Colorectal Cancer Risk Assessment Tool (https://ccrisktool.cancer.gov/calculator.html)

intervention.description: Patient receive personalized colorectal cancer risk assessment over the telephone by answering the questions as outlined in the National Cancer Institute Colorectal Cancer Risk Assessment Tool (https://ccrisktool.cancer.gov/calculator.html)
Patients receive standardized general information about colorectal cancer screening over the telephone.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient of any participating physician
- Not having had any colorectal cancer screening test prior
- Able to speak English
Exclusion Criteria:
- Personal history of inflammatory bowel disease
- Personal history of colorectal cancer
- Personal history of Lynch syndrome or Familial Adenomatous Polyposis
- Have already received colorectal cancer screening

link.description: National Cancer Institute Colorectal Cancer Risk Assessment Tool (CCRAT)

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Medicine, Director GI Cancer Prevention Program

patient_data.ipd_description: De-identified IPD will be made available to other researchers through a HIPAA compliant data storage system (Stanford Medicine Box) that is password protected
patient_data.ipd_access_criteria: Research staff solely associated with the study and/or Graduate or Post-Doc students-who are writing related manuscripts - who have been given permission by the Principal Investigator, Uri Ladabaum can submit a request.

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan
